title: Welcome to the IMSI Movement Science Course!
text:
The Integrative Movement Sciences Institute (IMSI) is a National Science Foundation (NSF) Biology Integration Institute dedicated to advancing the understanding of muscular control of movement across organizational scales—from molecular to organismal and ecological.
Our team of leading researchers from universities across the United States is creating a free, fully online course designed to share the excitement of movement science. The course is organized into individual modules covering a variety of movement science topics, which can be explored on their own or combined into curated learning pathways. You can browse modules to find those that spark your curiosity, or follow a recommended pathway to dive deeper into a specific area of the field.

title: About
text:
Include information about IMSI here
We can use Quarto to have a public facing website that is hosted on Github. Github can host all the code and PDF files, but videos are best hosted on YouTube.
We could alternatively format this in a more linear book format. See an example here: https://jjallaire.github.io/hopr/dice.html
Or more examples quarto websites and books here: https://quarto.org/docs/gallery/#websites

title: Scaling and dimensional analysis
text:
Describe the basic energy fluctuation patterns of walking and running in terrestrial gaits, as approximated by spring-loaded inverted pendulum models
Understand the basic principles of scaling with geometric similarity (or isometry), and state predictions for changes in strength and loading with increasing body size under the predictions of geometric similarity.
State the dynamic similarity hypothesis, and be able to generate predictions for dimensionless quantities according to the predictions of dynamic similarity. 
Use an example data set on gait of running birds to investigate how stride length and stride frequency vary with size, and visualize how the variation collapses when data are normalized to dimensionless quantities.



Presented by: Dr. Monica Daley

title: Scaling and dimensional analysis
text:
Additional reading
Alexander 1983
McMahon and Cheng 1990
Daley and Birn-Jeffery 2018

title: Scaling and dimensional analysis
section: Energy fluctuation patterns of walking and running in terrestrial gaits
text:
Energy fluctuation patterns of walking and running in terrestrial gaits
Walking and running gaits exhibit fundamentally different energy fluctuation patterns that can be understood through spring-loaded inverted pendulum models. In walking, the body operates as an inverted pendulum vaulting over a relatively stiff limb, with the leg acting at nearly fixed length during stance (as humans typically lock out the knee). This creates an out-of-phase relationship between gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy: when the foot first contacts the ground, velocity is at maximum, then kinetic energy converts to potential energy as the body reaches peak height at mid-stance, before reaccelerating and converting potential energy back to kinetic energy in the second half of stance. This passive energy exchange between kinetic and potential energies makes walking economical, requiring minimal external mechanical work on the center of mass. In contrast, running is characterized by bouncing motion where the leg acts as a compliant spring. The center of mass height decreases during stance rather than increasing, resulting in both kinetic energy and potential energy decreasing during the first half of stance and increasing during the second half. These in-phase fluctuations of external mechanical energies mean there cannot be an exchange between kinetic and potential energy; instead, energy is stored in elastic springs within the connective tissues (tendons, ligaments, and muscles) during the first half of stance and released during the second half. The spring-loaded inverted pendulum model, which combines both inverted pendulum and mass-spring dynamics, can account for the coupling between these two modes of motion and successfully predict ground reaction force patterns across diverse bipedal species.

title: Scaling and dimensional analysis
section: Principles of scaling with geometric similarity
text:
Principles of scaling with geometric similarity
The principle of isometric scaling (or geometric similarity) reveals fundamental challenges that arise when animals increase in body size while maintaining the same shape. When an object doubles in linear dimensions while preserving shape, its cross-sectional areas increase by the square of the length change (length²), while volume and mass increase by the cube of the length change (length³). This differential scaling creates a critical biomechanical problem: the ratio of cross-sectional area to mass decreases with increasing size (specifically, as one over length). Since strength in musculoskeletal tissues is proportional to cross-sectional area (scaling as length²) while loading is proportional to body mass (scaling as length³), animals that simply scale up geometrically become relatively weaker as they grow larger. This means larger animals experience relatively higher stresses on their tissues unless they compensate through shape changes. One observed compensation is that large animals adopt more upright, straight-legged postures, which align the bones vertically to better support body weight and reduce the muscular effort required to stand upright. This fundamental scaling challenge—that weight scales much faster than strength—has profound implications for how animals of different sizes must be structured and how they move, leading to systematic changes in both anatomy and locomotor function across the size range from the smallest shrews to the largest elephants.

title: Scaling and dimensional analysis
text:
Dynamic similarity hypothesis
The dynamic similarity hypothesis, developed by Alexander and colleagues in the 1970s-80s, proposes that if locomotor function remains constant across animals of different sizes, then size-related differences should disappear once data are normalized to dimensionless values using a standard set of characteristic physical quantities. For legged terrestrial locomotion, the appropriate base quantities are body mass, leg length, and gravity, derived from considering both inverted pendulum dynamics (with characteristic period related to √(L/g)) and mass-spring dynamics (with characteristic frequency related to √(k/m)). According to this hypothesis, all lengths and distances should be normalized by leg length, forces by body weight (mg), time by the characteristic pendular period √(L/g), frequency by √(g/L), and velocity by √(gL). An important dimensionless quantity is Froude number (v²/gL), which represents the ratio of inertial forces to gravitational forces and equals the square of dimensionless velocity; it is physically impossible for legged systems to walk at Froude numbers greater than one because centripetal accelerations would exceed gravitational acceleration. When locomotion data from species spanning vastly different body sizes are normalized using these dimensionless quantities, the dynamic similarity hypothesis predicts that all variation should collapse onto a single relationship. However, as demonstrated in the bird locomotion data, perfect collapse does not occur—while normalization does reduce variation significantly (particularly in stride frequency), systematic differences remain, with larger birds using relatively higher stride frequencies and shorter stride lengths than smaller birds. These deviations from perfect dynamic similarity reveal functionally important differences in how animals of different sizes actually move, such as large birds employing more vertically bouncy gaits while small birds use flatter center of mass trajectories, reflecting different mechanical strategies and constraints across the body size spectrum.
